content.title: Foreword
content.description:
This Technical Specification|Report has been produced by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP).
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within the TSG and may change following formal TSG approval. Should the TSG modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by the TSG with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows:
Version x.y.z
where:
x	the first digit:
1	presented to TSG for information;
2	presented to TSG for approval;
3	or greater indicates TSG approved document under change control.
y	the second digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, etc.
z	the third digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document.
In the present document, modal verbs have the following meanings:
shall	indicates a mandatory requirement to do something
shall not	indicates an interdiction (prohibition) to do something
The constructions "shall" and "shall not" are confined to the context of normative provisions, and do not appear in Technical Reports.
The constructions "must" and "must not" are not used as substitutes for "shall" and "shall not". Their use is avoided insofar as possible, and they are not used in a normative context except in a direct citation from an external, referenced, non-3GPP document, or so as to maintain continuity of style when extending or modifying the provisions of such a referenced document.
should	indicates a recommendation to do something
should not	indicates a recommendation not to do something
may	indicates permission to do something
need not	indicates permission not to do something
The construction "may not" is ambiguous and is not used in normative elements. The unambiguous constructions "might not" or "shall not" are used instead, depending upon the meaning intended.
can	indicates that something is possible
cannot	indicates that something is impossible
The constructions "can" and "cannot" are not substitutes for "may" and "need not".
will	indicates that something is certain or expected to happen as a result of action taken by an agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
will not	indicates that something is certain or expected not to happen as a result of action taken by an agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
might	indicates a likelihood that something will happen as a result of action taken by some agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
might not	indicates a likelihood that something will not happen as a result of action taken by some agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
In addition:
is	(or any other verb in the indicative mood) indicates a statement of fact
is not	(or any other negative verb in the indicative mood) indicates a statement of fact
The constructions "is" and "is not" do not indicate requirements.

content.title: 1	Scope
content.description: The present document is a technical report for the work item of the NTN L-S-band.

content.title: 2	References
content.description:
The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present document.
-	References are either specific (identified by date of publication, edition number, version number, etc.) or non-specific.
-	For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply.
-	For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies. In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document (including a GSM document), a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document in the same Release as the present document.
[1]	3GPP TR 21.905: "Vocabulary for 3GPP Specifications".
[2]	3GPP TS 38.108: "NR; Satellite Access Node radio transmission and reception"

content.title: 3	Definitions of terms, symbols and abbreviations

subsections.title: 3.1	Terms
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the terms given in TR 21.905 [1] and the following apply. A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition of the same term, if any, in TR 21.905 [1].
Non-terrestrial networks: Networks, or segments of networks, using an airborne or space-borne vehicle to embark a transmission equipment relay node or base station.
Satellite: A space-borne vehicle embarking a bent pipe payload or a regenerative payload telecommunication transmitter, placed into Low-Earth Orbit (LEO), Medium-Earth Orbit (MEO), or Geostationary Earth Orbit (GEO).
Satellite Access Node: see definition in TS 38.108 [2].
UE transmission bandwidth configuration: Set of resource blocks located within the UE channel bandwidth which may be used for transmitting or receiving by the UE.

subsections.title: 3.2	Symbols
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the following symbols apply:
ΔFGlobal	Granularity of the global frequency raster
ΔFRaster	Band dependent channel raster granularity
BWChannel	Channel bandwidth
BWinterferer	Bandwidth of the interferer
FDL_low	The lowest frequency of the downlink operating band
FDL_high	The highest frequency of the downlink operating band
FUL_low	The lowest frequency of the uplink operating band
FUL_high	The highest frequency of the uplink operating band
FInterferer	Frequency of the interferer
FInterferer (offset)	Frequency offset of the interferer (between the center frequency of the interferer and the carrier frequency of the carrier measured)
FIoffset	Frequency offset of the interferer (between the center frequency of the interferer and the closest edge of the carrier measured)
FOOB	The boundary between the NR out of band emission and spurious emission domains
FREF	RF reference frequency
FREF-Offs	Offset used for calculating FREF
Fuw (offset)	The frequency separation of the center frequency of the carrier closest to the interferer and the center frequency of the interferer
NRB	Transmission bandwidth configuration, expressed in units of resource blocks
NREF	NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number (NR-ARFCN)
NREF-Offs	Offset used for calculating NREF
PInterferer	Modulated mean power of the interferer
Puw	Power of an unwanted DL signal

subsections.title: 3.3	Abbreviations
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the abbreviations given in TR 21.905 [1] and the following apply. An abbreviation defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition of the same abbreviation, if any, in TR 21.905 [1].
ACLR	Adjacent Channel Leakage Ratio
ACS	Adjacent Channel Selectivity
A-MPR	Additional Maximum Power Reduction
BW	Bandwidth
BWP	Bandwidth Part
CP-OFDM	Cyclic Prefix-OFDM
CW	Continuous Wave
DFT-s-OFDM	Discrete Fourier Transform-spread-OFDM
EIRP	Equivalent Isotropically Radiated Power
EVM	Error Vector Magnitude
FR	Frequency Range
FRC	Fixed Reference Channel
GEO	Geosynchronous Earth Orbit
GSCN	Global Synchronization Channel Number
IBB	In-band Blocking
ITU-R	Radiocommunication Sector of the International Telecommunication Union
LEO	Low Earth Orbiting
MOP	Maximum Output Power
MPR	Allowed maximum power reduction
MSD	Maximum Sensitivity Degradation
NR	New Radio
NR-ARFCN	NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number
NS	Network Signalling
NTN	Non-Terrestrial Network
OOB	Out-of-band
PRB	Physical Resource Block
QAM	Quadrature Amplitude Modulation
RAN	Radio Access Network
RE	Resource Element
REFSENS	REFerence SENSitivity
RF	Radio Frequency
RMS	Root Mean Square (value)
RX	Receiver
SAN	Satellite Access Node
SC	Single Carrier
SCS	Subcarrier spacing
SEM	Spectrum Emission Mask
SNR	Signal-to-Noise Ratio
SS	Synchronization Symbol
TN	Terrestrial Network
TX	Transmitter
UE	User Equipment

content.title: 4	Background
content.description:
3GPP RAN#86 meeting approved the Rel-17 WI that aimed to enable support of the 5G/NR radio access technology for non-terrestrial satellite deployments. One of the WI objectives was to define and introduce the corresponding bands into the 3GPP specifications. The outcome of these discussions was two NTN bands – L-band and S-band – which were added as bands n255 and n256, respectively. At the same time there exist other satellite deployments, some of which use mixed L-/S-band pairing, whereupon the UL part is on the L-band, while the DL part is on the S-band. To limit the overall workload in Rel-17, it was decided by RAN WG4 to focus on L- and S-bands with the common understanding that other potential NTN bands should follow the "normal" process of submitting a new spectrum WI.
3GPP RAN#98 meeting agreed a new spectrum WI to add support for a new NTN band with the DL part on the S-band (2500MHz) and the UL part on the L-band (1600MHz).

content.title: 5	Regulations
content.description: NOTE:	The purpose of this section is to collect information from existing regulatory documents concerning regulatory rules applicable to this NTN L-/S-band.

subsubsections.title: 5.1.1	47 CFR § 25.202
5.1.2	47 CFR § 25.216
subsubsections.text_content: (c) The e.i.r.p. density of emissions from mobile earth stations placed in service after July 21, 2002 with assigned uplink frequencies between 1610 MHz and 1660.5 MHz shall not exceed −70 dBW/MHz, averaged over any 2 millisecond active transmission interval, in the band 1559-1605 MHz. The e.i.r.p. of discrete emissions of less than 700 Hz bandwidth from such stations shall not exceed −80 dBW, averaged over any 2 millisecond active transmission interval, in the 1559-1605 MHz band.

subsubsections.title: 5.2.1	ETSI EN 301 441
subsubsections.text_content:
Table 5.2.1-1: Mobile Satellite Service frequency bands

Table 5.2.1-2: Maximum unwanted emissions outside the band 1610 MHz to 1626.5 MHz and the band 1626.5 MHz to 1628.5MHz.

Table 5.2.1-3: Maximum unwanted emissions within the band 1610MHz to 1 626.5MHz and the band 1626.5 MHz to 1628.5MHz of MES operating such that the nominated bandwidth is entirely or partially contained in the frequency band 1618.25 MHz to 1626.5MHz.

Table 5.2.1-4: Maximum unwanted emissions within the band 1610MHz to 1626.5 MHz and the band 1626.5MHz to 1628.5MHz of MES operating such that the nominated bandwidth is entirely contained in the frequency band 1610MHz to 1618.25MHz.

Table 5.2.1-5: Maximum unwanted emissions of MES carriers within the operational band of CDMA carriers.

The frequency offset and relative power level of the adjacent signal compared to the wanted signal shall take the values given in table 5.2.1-6. The adjacent signal shall occupy the same bandwidth as the wanted signal where BW is the wanted signal occupied bandwidth. There shall be no more than 0.5dB degradation in the receiver signal to noise ratio under these conditions.
Table 5.2.1-6: Adjacent Channel frequency and power level

Receiver blocking characteristics are to prevent high power signals outside the receive frequency band from blocking the reception of signals inside the receive frequency band. The blocking characteristic is a measure of the receiver's ability to receive a wanted signal at its assigned channel frequency in the presence of an unwanted interferer on frequencies other than those of the spurious response or the adjacent channels, without this unwanted input signal causing a degradation of the performance of the receiver beyond a specified limit. Receiver blocking is specified for in-band signals. In-band signals are signals in the range:
BEL-10MHz to BEU +10 MHz, where BEL and BEU are the lower and upper edges of the operating band respectively.
The receiver performance degradation, in terms of signal to noise ratio, shall not exceed 1dB when the unwanted signal as specified in Table 5.2.1-7 is present.

Table 5.2.1-7: Test parameters for in-band blocking characteristics

subsubsections.title: 6.2.1	UE transmitter characteristics
subsubsections.text_content:
Table 6.2.1.1-1: NTN L-/S-band n254 Power Class

Maximum power reduction for the NTN L-/S-band is the same as for other NTN bands, such as L-band n255 and S-band n256.
Table 6.2.1.2.1-1: Maximum power reduction (MPR) for power class 3.

Maximum power reduction for the NTN L-/S-band is the same as for other NTN bands, such as L-band n255 and S-band n256.
6.2.1.2.2.1		Configuration cases
For the power back-off simulations the following common parameters are assumed:
-	Tx power: PC3 +23dBm
-	LO placement: always in the centre of the carrier
-	Regulations: ETSI and FCC

The following channel sizes with centre frequencies are considered:
-	NR 5MHz channel at the following centre frequencies:
a)	Fc=1612.5MHz
b)	Fc=1613.9MHz
c)	Fc=1615.5MHz
d)	Fc=1620.5MHz
e)	Fc=1622.4MHz
f)	Fc=1624MHz

-	NR 10MHz channel at the following centre frequencies:
a)	Fc=1615MHz.
b)	Fc=1620MHz
c)	Fc=1621.5MHz
-	NR 15MHz channel at the following centre frequencies:
a)	Fc=1617.5MHz
b)	Fc=1619MHz

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 -1 presents a detailed analysis of considered channels for A-MPR simulations. The figure illustrates various propagation channels, including LOS, NLOS, and shadowed areas, which are essential for understanding the performance of A-MPR systems. The channels are represented by different colors and patterns, with LOS and NLOS channels depicted in solid lines and shadowed areas in dashed lines. The figure also includes a legend to clarify the different channel types and their characteristics. This information is crucial for designing and optimizing A-MPR systems to ensure reliable and efficient communication in complex environments.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1-1: Considered channels for A-MPR simulations.

6.2.1.2.2.2	Power back-off results for ETSI
6.2.1.2.2.2.1	5MHz channel

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 -1: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1612.5MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 5MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1612.5MHz. The figure shows a step-by-step process of how the power level of the signal decreases as it travels through the channel, with each step representing a different power back-off value. This is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference in the communication system. The figure also highlights the importance of precise power management in modern telecommunication networks.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-1: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1612.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 - 2 presents a detailed breakdown of power back-off values for a 5MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1613.9MHz. The figure illustrates the step-wise reduction in transmitted power as the signal moves through various frequency bands, ensuring a smooth transition between adjacent channels and preventing interference. The visual representation emphasizes the importance of precise power management in maintaining efficient communication within the specified frequency range.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-2: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1613.9MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 - 3 illustrates the power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1615.5 MHz, which is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference in a wireless communication system. The figure shows the relationship between the back-off value and the frequency offset, demonstrating how adjusting the power level can optimize performance in a 5MHz channel. The visual representation of this relationship is essential for understanding how to configure wireless systems for optimal performance.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-3: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1615.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1 - 4 illustrates the power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at a frequency of 16.20.5 MHz. The figure shows a step-by-step process of how the power levels decrease as the frequency increases, with each step representing a different power level. The figure is essential for understanding the proper power allocation in a wireless communication system, ensuring efficient and reliable data transmission.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-4: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1620.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 - 5 presents a detailed breakdown of power back-off values for a 5MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1622.4MHz. The figure illustrates the step-by-step process of how the power level of the signal decreases as it travels through the channel, ensuring a smooth and efficient transmission. The visual representation of the power levels provides a clear understanding of how the signal strength is managed, which is crucial for maintaining reliable communication in wireless networks.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-5: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1622.4MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 - 6 illustrates the power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at a frequency of Fc=16, with a range of 24 MHz. The figure demonstrates the relationship between the channel bandwidth and the power back-off, which is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference in a wireless communication system. The visual representation includes a grid with horizontal and vertical axes, where the horizontal axis represents the channel bandwidth in MHz, and the vertical axis represents the power back-off in dBm. The data points are plotted on the grid, showing how the power back-off changes with different channel bandwidths. This information is essential for engineers designing wireless communication systems, as it helps them optimize the power back-off to achieve the desired signal quality and system performance.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-6: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1624MHz.

6.2.1.2.2.2.2	10MHz channel

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2 -1: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at  Fc=16 15 MHz, illustrates the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel at a frequency of 16.15 MHz. The figure shows a step-by-step process of how the power back-off is calculated, starting with the initial power level and then reducing it in steps based on the frequency and channel conditions. The figure is essential for understanding the power management in wireless communication systems and ensuring efficient use of the available spectrum.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2-1: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1615MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2 -2: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1620MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1620MHz. The figure shows a step-by-step process of how the power level of the signal decreases as it travels through the channel, with each step representing a different power back-off value. This is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference in the communication system. The figure also highlights the importance of precise power management in modern telecommunication networks.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2-2: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1620MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2 - 3 presents a telecommunication scenario illustrating the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel at a frequency of 16.215 MHz. The figure showcases the relationship between the channel bandwidth and the power back-off, which is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference. The visual representation includes a frequency spectrum with labeled frequency bands, a channel bandwidth, and a power back-off curve. The curve demonstrates the gradual decrease in transmitted power as the channel bandwidth increases, ensuring that adjacent channels remain distinct and communication remains efficient. This information is vital for understanding the performance of telecommunication systems and designing appropriate power management strategies.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.2-3: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1621.5MHz.

6.2.1.2.2.2.3	15MHz channel

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.3 -1: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=16 17.5 MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 15MHz channel with a frequency reuse factor (Fc) of 16 at 17.5 MHz. The figure provides a visual representation of how the power levels are reduced over time to prevent interference between adjacent channels. The x-axis represents the time in milliseconds, while the y-axis represents the power level in dBm. The curve shows a gradual decrease in power, indicating that the power back-off is applied over a period of time to ensure a smooth transition between channels. This figure is important for understanding the technical aspects of power management in telecommunication systems, particularly in the context of frequency reuse and channel planning.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.3-1: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=1617.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.3 -2: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at  Fc=16 19 MHz, illustrates the power back-off values for a 15MHz channel with a frequency center (Fc) of 16.19 MHz. The figure shows the relationship between the power back-off and the frequency offset, which is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference in wireless communication systems. The power back-off values are used to ensure that the signal strength remains within acceptable limits, while also allowing for some flexibility in the frequency allocation. The figure provides a visual representation of these complex mathematical relationships, making it easier for engineers and technicians to understand and apply these concepts in their work.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.3-2: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=1619MHz.


Figure 6.2.1.2.2. 3 .1 -1: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1612.5MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 5MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1612.5MHz. The figure shows a series of bars representing the power levels, with the back-off values indicated by the numerical labels. The back-off values are crucial for managing interference and ensuring proper signal quality in the communication system. The bars are arranged in descending order, with the highest power level at the top and the lowest at the bottom, reflecting the power back-off requirements for the channel. The figure is a valuable resource for understanding the power management strategies in telecommunication systems, particularly in the context of frequency reuse and interference avoidance.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.1-1: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1612.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.1 -2: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1613.9MHz illustrates the power back-off values for a 5MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1613.9MHz. The figure shows a series of bars representing the power back-off values, with the highest bar indicating the maximum power level and the lowest bar representing the minimum power level. The bars are arranged in a descending order, with the maximum power level at the top and the minimum power level at the bottom. This figure is important for understanding the power management and channel allocation in a wireless communication system.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.2.1-2: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1613.9MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2. 3 .1 - 3 presents a detailed analysis of power back-off values for a 5MHz channel at a frequency of 1615.5 MHz. The figure illustrates the relationship between the back-off value and the channel bandwidth, providing valuable insights into the optimal settings for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference. The visual representation includes a logarithmic scale for the back-off values, emphasizing the importance of precise adjustments in this parameter. The figure is essential for engineers and technicians working on wireless communication systems, as it helps them understand the impact of power back-off on signal strength and stability.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.1-3: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1615.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2. 3 .1 - 4 presents a detailed analysis of power back-off values for a 5MHz channel at a frequency of 16.20.5 MHz. The figure illustrates the relationship between the back-off values and the channel bandwidth, providing valuable insights into the optimal settings for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference. The visual representation of the data allows for a clear understanding of how these parameters impact the overall performance of the communication system.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.1-4: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1620.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2. 3 .1 - 5 presents a series of power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at a frequency of Fc=16 to 24 MHz. The figure illustrates the relationship between the channel bandwidth and the power back-off, which is crucial for maintaining efficient communication and avoiding interference in a wireless network. The values are presented in a descending order, indicating that the power back-off is higher at lower frequencies and decreases as the frequency increases. This information is essential for network designers and engineers to ensure optimal performance and coverage in their wireless communication systems.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.1-5: Power back-off values for the 5MHz channel at Fc=1624MHz.

6.2.1.2.2.3.2	10MHz channel

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.2 -1: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at  Fc=16 15 MHz, illustrates the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel at a frequency of 16.15 MHz. The figure shows the relationship between the power back-off and the frequency, with the power back-off values decreasing as the frequency increases. This information is important for understanding the performance of the wireless communication system and ensuring that the system operates efficiently and reliably.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.2-1: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1615MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.2 -2: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1620MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel operating at a frequency of 1620MHz. The figure shows a step-by-step process of how the power level of the signal decreases as it travels through the channel, with each step representing a different power back-off value. Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.2 - 3 presents a telecommunication scenario illustrating the power back-off values for a 10MHz channel at a frequency of 16.215 MHz. The figure showcases the relationship between the channel bandwidth and the power back-off, which is crucial for maintaining signal quality and preventing interference. The visual representation includes a frequency spectrum with labeled frequency bands, a channel bandwidth, and a power back-off curve. The curve demonstrates the gradual decrease in transmitted power as the channel bandwidth increases, ensuring that adjacent channels remain distinct and communication remains efficient. This information is vital for understanding the performance of telecommunication systems and designing appropriate power management strategies.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.2-3: Power back-off values for the 10MHz channel at Fc=1621.5MHz.

6.2.1.2.2.3.3	15MHz channel

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.3 -1: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=16 17.5 MHz. This telecommunication figure illustrates the power back-off values for a 15MHz channel with a frequency reuse factor (Fc) of 16 at 17.5 MHz. The figure provides a visual representation of how the power levels are reduced over time to prevent interference between adjacent channels. The x-axis represents the time in milliseconds, while the y-axis represents the power level in dBm. The curve shows a gradual decrease in power as time progresses, ensuring a smooth transition between channels and maintaining efficient communication.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.3-1: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=1617.5MHz.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.3 -2: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at  Fc=16 19 MHz, illustrates the power back-off values for a 15MHz channel in a wireless communication system. The figure shows the relationship between the frequency offset (Fc) and the power back-off value, which is used to manage interference and ensure proper communication between devices. The power back-off values are crucial for maintaining the quality of service in a wireless network. The figure provides a clear visual representation of how these values are calculated and how they impact the overall performance of the network.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.3.3-2: Power back-off values for the 15MHz channel at Fc=1619MHz.
6.2.1.2.2.4	Summary of the power back-off values
Presented power back-off values can be summarised as follows:
-	NR channels placed at the leftmost edge of the band might need power back-off, exact value of which depends on the number of the scheduled RBs and their location. Results are the same for both FCC and ETSI requirements because the main limiting factor is the out-of-band emission requirements, which are the same for both regulatory domains. In other words, even though ETSI has additional in-band emission requirements for 1610-1618MHz, they do not impact results. 6.2.1.2.2.4-1 illustrates power spectrum of the fully allocated 5MHz channel right at the lower edge of the band showing that unless power back-off is applied out of band emission requirements will be violated.
-	As somewhat anticipated, RBs scheduled at the centre of the NR channel do not require any power back-off; but RBs scheduled at the leftmost edge of the configured NR channel do require power back-off to meet out-of-band emission requirements. Similarly, power back-off is needed when all RBs are scheduled to mitigate emissions coming from the full-channel transmissions.
-	In case of the 5MHz channel, once the channel is shifted farther from the left edge of the band where the GNSS services are, the required power back-off goes down a lot and is caused mostly by the in-band emission requirements. For instance, if the 5MHz NR channel is shifted by 1.4MHz from the lower edge, then small RB allocations will not require any power back-off at all. Some of the channel edge allocations might need power back-off, but it does not exceed baseline MPR. For both FCC and ETSI regulations the switching point is around the center frequency of 1615.7MHz, after which power back-off values remain limited to the basic MPR requirements for any configuration case.
-	The 5MHz channel placed at the rightmost edge of the band may need some A-MPR for the RBs scheduled at the right edge of the channel under the ETSI regulations because the latter have out-of-band emission requirements for higher frequencies. 6.2.1.2.2.4-2 shows the power spectrum plot for the right-most channel, from which one can see that unless a UE applies power back-off the ETSI out-of-band emission requirements can be violated. Nevertheless, once the channel is shifted away from the upper edge by 1.6MHz, no A-MPR is needed at least for small allocations. And under the FCC regulations no A-MPR is needed even for the right-most channel because there are no out-of-band emission requirements for higher frequencies.
-	As for the 10 and 15MHz channels, even if we shift the channel to the right from the leftmost band edge, some configuration cases would still require A-MPR irrespective of whether it is ETSI or FCC requirements. As in cases for other channels at the band edge, A-MPR is needed mostly for the case when all RBs are scheduled. The only difference between FCC and ETSI power back-off values is that FCC will trigger lower A-MPR because there are no out-of-band emission requirements for upper frequencies and no in-band emission requirements.

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4 - 1 presents a power spectrum plot for a CP-OFDM transmission with a fully allocated 5MHz bandwidth, centered at 1612.5MHz. The plot illustrates the spectral distribution of the transmitted signal, revealing the presence of multiple subcarriers within the allocated frequency range. The spectrum is characterized by a series of peaks and troughs, indicating the presence of different frequency components. The peaks represent the strongest signals, while the troughs indicate weaker signals. The plot is essential for analyzing the performance of the CP-OFDM system and ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4-1: Power spectrum plot for the CP-OFDM 5MHz fully allocated transmission (Fc=1612.5MHz).

Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4 - 2 presents a power spectrum plot for a CP-OFDM transmission with fully allocated bandwidth, where the center frequency (Fc) is set at 16 MHz. The plot illustrates the distribution of power across different frequency components, providing insights into the spectral efficiency of the transmission. The visual representation of the power spectrum highlights the efficient use of the allocated bandwidth, ensuring minimal interference and maximizing data throughput.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4-2: Power spectrum plot for the CP-OFDM 5MHz fully allocated transmission (Fc=1624MHz MHz).

If an operator decides to ensure lower power back-off, then one of the possible approaches is to rely upon 5MHz channels and to configure them with offsets from the lower/upper band edges. Then to avoid wasting 1.4/1.6MHz at the edges of the band it is possible to deploy other technologies, such as LTE CatM and NB-IOT. Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4-3 shows an exemplary allocation of channels, where an operator may consider one LTE CatM channel or seven NB-IOT channels at the lower edge of the band. For the upper edge, either eight NB-IOT channels can be configured, or one LTE CatM channel can be combined with one NB-IOT channel.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4 - 3 presents an illustrative example of channel allocations at the extremities of the frequency spectrum. The figure showcases the distribution of channels, with various bands assigned to different services and users. The visual representation emphasizes the strategic placement of channels to optimize network efficiency and minimize interference. The figure highlights the importance of careful planning in spectrum management, particularly in the context of 5G and beyond, where the demand for bandwidth is high and the need for spectrum efficiency is critical.
Figure 6.2.1.2.2.4-3: Exemplary allocations of channels at the edges of the band.

This sub-clause contains additional simulations to evaluate the magnitude of A-MPR. The simulations assumptions are as presented below:
-	PA calibration point: ACLR of 30 dBc is met with DFT-s-OFDM waveform with StartRB = 0, L_CRB = 100
-	IQ-image: -28 dBc
-	LO-leakage: -28 dBc
-	CIM3: -60 dBc
-	Additional requirements: NR ACLR, SEM, Spurious emissions, EVM, Additional out of band bands emissions from ETSI EN 301 441

This section presents results from the power back-off measurements taken for the left-most 5, 10 and 15MHz channels following the out-of-band emission requirements that are common for both the ETSI and FCC:
-	PC3 PA calibrated for 4dB post PA losses, 30dB ACLR at MPR1 for 20MHz DFT-s-OFDM QPSK
-	Fully allocated waveform for QPSK DFT-s-OFDM and CP-OFDM
-	Measurement every 0.5MHz in the slope and peak in 1MHz for the -40dBm/MHz floor.
Measurements results are presented in Table 6.2.1.2.4-1 below, for which the following summary can be made:
-	For the 5MHz channel:
-	Back-off is needed for emissions at 3.5MHz offset
-	MPR is not sufficient for DFT-s-OFDM but is sufficient for CP-OFDM up to 4.5MHz offset
-	Maximum back-off is needed to meet -40dBm/MHz floor at 5MHz offset at:
-	2.0dB for DFT-s-OFDM
-	5.5dB for CP-OFDM.
-	For the 10MHz channel:
-	Back-off is needed for emissions at 2.5MHz offset
-	MPR is sufficient up to 3MHz offset for DFT-s-OFDM and CP-OFDM
-	Maximum back-off is needed to meet -40dBm/MHz floor at 5MHz offset at:
-	6.0dB for DFT-s-OFDM
-	8.3dB for CP-OFDM.
-	For the 15MHz channel:
-	Back-off is needed for emissions at 2.5MHz offset
-	MPR is sufficient up to 3MHz offset for DFT-s-OFDM and CP-OFDM
-	Maximum back-off is needed to meet -40dBm/MHz floor at 5MHz offset at:
-	5.2dB for DFT-s-OFDM
-	8.5dB for CP-OFDM.

Table 6.2.1.2.4-1: Back-off measurement results for frequencies with issues

Tables 6.2.1.2.5-1 - 6.2.1.2.5-3 below present "harmonised" A-MPR values for 5, 10 and 15MHz channels at reference frequencies considered for the power back-off simulations and measurements. For the sake of simplicity only "full" RB allocation cases are used to compare results from different sources.
Table 6.2.1.2.5-1: Harmonised A-MPR values for the 5MHz channel.

Table 6.2.1.2.5-2: Harmonised A-MPR values for the 10MHz channel.

Table 6.2.1.2.5-3: Harmonised A-MPR values for the 15MHz channel.

There are three additional NS values defined for this band as summarised in Table 6.2.1.3-1 below:
a)	NS_03N is for the FCC regulatory domain. Since FCC does not introduce any special in-band emission requirements for sub-ranges, same requirements will be applicable for the whole range and for all the channel sizes.
b)	ETSI regulations have different in-band emission masks depending on the operating sub-range, so two NS flags are needed to differentiate between them.
c)	NS_04N applicable range is limited to 1610-1618.25MHz according to the ETSI requirements. And since the total spectrum block size is 8.25MHz, it can accommodate only 5MHz standard NR channel, i.e. the applicable NR channel size is 5MHz.
d)	NS_04N is for the ETSI range 1618.25-1626.5MHz, which can also accommodate only 5MHz standard NR channel. However, ETSI document also clarifies that the same in-band emission requirements will apply if the channel is partially configured in that range. It means that any 10 and 15MHz channel configured in 1610-1626.5MHz range will inevitably fall into the 1618.25-1626.5MHz range and thus they will follow NS_04N requirements.
Table 6.2.1.3-1: NTN L-/S-band NS values

Mapping between values of additionalSpectrumEmission and NS values is given in the Table 6.2.3.1-2 below.
Table 6.2.1.3-2: Mapping of network signalling label

For the 5MHz channel, Figure 6.2.1.3a-1 below presents a graphical summary of the required power back-off values for different 5MHz channels:
-	The 5MHz channel right at the lower edge of the band requires power back-off even for small RB allocations irrespective of the fact whether it is FCC or ETSI regulations. If the channel is shifted by 1.4MHz, then at least small RB allocations will not require power back-off exceeding baseline MPR requirements. Shifting the 5MHz channel beyond the 1615.7MHz centre frequency results in no A-MPR at all.
-	As for the upper edge of the band, the 5MHz channel under the FCC regulations will not require any additional A-MPR requirements even if it is right at the edge because there are no out-of-band emission requirements for the upper frequencies. However, with the ETSI regulations we will need to provide offset of 1.6MHz, upon which we will not be exceeding baseline MPR requirements.
-	Because of the same regulations for the lower frequencies, A-MPR values can be the same for NS_03N (FCC) and NS_04N (ETSI lower range) at centre frequencies 1612.5 <= fc < 1615.7MHz. Furthermore, it is possible to split A-MPR values into two regions – 1612.5 <= fc < 1613.9MHz and 1613.9 <= fc < 1615.7MHz – whereupon the second region will not require A-MPR for small RB allocations.
-	There is no need for A-MPR for NS_03N (FCC) at centre frequencies above 1615.7MHz, but NS_05N (ETSI upper range) requires A-MPR for center frequencies at 1622.4 < fc <= 1624MHz.


Figure 6.2.1.3a - 1 presents a summary of the required power back-off regions for the 5MHz channel, as mandated by both the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). The top portion of the figure illustrates the power back-off regions under FCC regulations, while the bottom portion represents the regions under ETSI guidelines. The figure is a visual representation of the necessary distance between base stations to ensure compliance with the specified regulations, which are crucial for maintaining efficient and safe communication networks.
Figure 6.2.1.3a-1: Summary of required power back-off regions for the 5MHz channel for FCC (top) and ETSI (bottom) regulations.
For the 10MHz channel:
-	For the channel right at the lower edge of the band, A-MPR might be needed even for small RB allocations at the channel edges because of the strict out-of-band emission requirements. Shifting the channel farther away from the lower edge basically improves A-MPR with the switching point at the centre frequency of around 1620.1MHz (i.e. 1.4MHz offset from the upper edge), after which at least for the ETSI requirements emission requirements from the upper frequencies start influencing allocations at the channel’s upper edge. Based on that A-MPR values can be considered the same for NS_03N (FCC) and NS_05N (ETSI) for the centre frequencies at 1615 <= fc < 1620.1MHz.
-	For the channel right at the upper edge of the band, A-MPR is generally not needed for small allocations under the FCC regulations, which is reflected in the corresponding A-MPR for NS_03 for the channel at 1621.5MHz. However, with NS_05N (ETSI) A-MPR is still required because of the out-of-band emission requirements for upper frequencies.
-	As can be seen from Figure 6.2.1.3a-2 below, the only major difference between the FCC and ETSI A-MPR regions is that the former can have optimised 10MHz channel placed right at the upper edge of the band.


Figure 6.2.1.3a - 2 presents a summary of the required power back-off regions for the 10MHz channel, as mandated by both the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). The top portion of the figure illustrates the power back-off regions under FCC regulations, while the bottom portion represents the regions under ETSI guidelines. The figure is a visual representation of the necessary distance between base stations to ensure compliance with regulations and avoid interference. The color-coded regions indicate the minimum required distance in kilometers for different power levels, providing a clear understanding of the spatial separation required for each power level. This information is crucial for network operators to ensure efficient and compliant deployment of their wireless infrastructure.
Figure 6.2.1.3a-2: Summary of required power back-off regions for the 10MHz channel for FCC (top) and ETSI (bottom) regulations.

For the 15MHz channel, more or less same A-MPR is needed for NS_03N (FCC) and NS_05N (ETSI) irrespective of the fact where exactly the channel is configured and whether it is under the FCC or ETSI regulations.



Figure 6.2.1.3a - 3 presents a detailed representation of A-MPR (Access and Mobility Management Radius) regions for a network named NS_03N, which operates at three distinct frequency channels: 5, 10, and 15 MHz. The figure illustrates the geographical distribution of these regions, highlighting the coverage areas and the interconnections between them. This information is crucial for network administrators to understand the network's capacity, coverage, and potential for seamless connectivity across different frequency bands. The figure emphasizes the importance of efficient management of radio resources and the coordination of access and mobility within the network.
Figure 6.2.1.3a-3: A-MPR regions for NS_03N (5, 10 and 15MHz channels).

Table 6.2.1.3a-2: A-MPR values for NS_04N (ETSI lower sub-range)
Table 6.2.1.3a-3: A-MPR values for NS_05N (ETSI upper sub-range)
Table 6.2.1.4-1: Requirements for spurious emissions for UE co-existence

subsubsections.title: 6.2.2	UE receiver characteristics
subsubsections.text_content:
For band n254, band n53 REFSENS is re-used with additional 0.5dB insertion loss. The corresponding band n254 REFSENS values are presented in Table 6.2.2.1-1 below.
Table 6.2.2.1-1: NTN L-/S-band two antenna port reference sensitivity QPSK PREFSENS

Table 6.2.2.2-1: NTN L-/S-band in-band blocking

For band n254, same out-of-band blocking requirements as for the band n53 are re-used, whereupon Range 3 exception is adjusted accordingly accounting for the fact that band n254 upper bound is at 2500MHz.
Table 6.2.2.3-1: Out of-band blocking requirements.

Table 6.2.2.2-1: NTN L-/S-band in-band blocking
Table 6.2.2.3-1: Out of-band blocking requirements.

subsubsections.title: 6.2.3	UE RRM requirements
subsubsections.text_content: There are no RRM specific requirements associated with this band.

subsections.title: 6.3	SAN requirements
subsections.text_content: There are no SAN RF specific requirements associated with this band.
